div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,562] ALEXANDRIA, FRIDAY, AUGUST 3, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday until 4 June, and then every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at TOR (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Venice every Wednesday about 8:30 a.m. in time for Express Switzerland, Paris and London leaving Venice 2 p.m. and 11.20 p.m. Arrival Trieste every Wednesday about 3 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and luggage-van attached every Saturday to Express leaving Cairo 9.30 a.m. and are conveyed direcly to Quay alongside steamer.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.

div.head: REFORM OF COMPANY LAW.
div.p: In oor last article on this subject we referred to the way in which the Commission appointed to report npon the amendment of Company Liw in the United Kingdom (called for by the serious falling-off in the registration of of limited companies, the transfer of snob business to foreign countries, and the growing practice of issuing companies without pros­pectus) proposed to make registration more popular and to prevent these regrettable results, mainly arising from the passii g of the Aofc of 1900.

We will now deal with that portion of their report which refers to registration outside the United Kingdom of companies carrying on business in England and appealing to English investors. It is, they state, as a matter of course desirable that as maLy oompanies as possible, oondneting enterprises abroad, should be controlled from the United Kingdom. "The promoter also finds it more convenient to register in the country where he has to get his capital—which is usually England—thm in the oonntry which is to he the soene of the company's operations." They also seem to he agreed that the practice of using onr registra­tion laws for foreign enterprise ia changing and that some means should be taken to restore this praotice to its former oondition

of popularity, which they think may be effected by making the law as to disclosure or the liability of directors less stringent icd the stamp duty less deterrent. Without goitg to the length of recommending the compel­ling of foreign companies carrying on business in the United Kingdom to comply with the requirements of the Act of 1900, they are of opinion that every foreign company having any place of business in the United Kingdom should he required under penalty to file in England a verified copy, with a verified English translation, of its charter, statutes, or memorandum and articles of association, with the names of all directors and with the name of the authorized representative acting on behalf of each company who would represent the same for services of processes or legal pro­ceedings. Also that foreign company shall file with the Registrar a verified copy cf its annual balance sheet under substantial penal* ty for default. Further, that a foreign com­pany of this kind using the word ''Limited' should in any prospers inviting subscriptions in the United Kingdom state the company's place of origin and should when carrying on basinets in the United Kingdom he compelled
under penalty to put its place of origin with its own name on its business premises.

It should be steadily borne in mind that these recommendations are made with a view of protecting the shareholders and creditors of snob companies and not with any idea of bringing them into any other position than they are now as regards taxation,whioh subject was not in the scope of the enquiry. We can­not but consider these recommendations m entirely reasonable. If companies starting on some foreign project expect to obtain capital to carry on such enterprises from England, the British public. have a right to have open to them the faots and figures relating to them, and the foreigner, where he deals in shares of a company termed "Limited," has a right to expeot to see its registration papers at Somer­set House ; as the word "limited" implies that it is registered subject to the various Acts of Parliament passsd under the Limited Liability Aots for the proteotion both of shareholders and creditors as wall as the general public.

We should doubt if obligations of this kind would have much effect iu preventing foreign companies with English capital being started, but the other recommendations to meet this among other grievances, i.e., lowering the cost of the stamp on the capital authorized from os. % to 2s. 6d. % and the payment of the same by instalments as well as the less stringent treatment of honest directors, wonld without doubt make registration in England of public oompanies, both foreign and otherwise, increasingly popular. The Act of 190) felt by all who had knowledge ot the subject as based upon the idea that the balk of com­pany promoters and even directors were rogues, and in trying to improve the law the assump­tion mast be that the company promoter fi Is a real want and has a right to be protected just as mach as the pahlio themselves. Thera is nothing in the least derogatory in oompaoy promotion so long as all is above board, yet the effect of the Act of 1900 was to make any (good business man ashamed of the appellation pfrom the sinister view it oast npon his profession.

Iu the matter of foreign oompanies Egypt is very much a case in point It is a great pity that any attempt should be made to evade registration of any oompanies trading in Egypt and having business premises in England. At present the share markets in Alexandria and Cairo are apparently good enough for most pnrposes, but Egyptian companies wonld be short-sighted indeed who did not see an element of pradenoe in the placing of their position quite clearly before those whose asristanoe tb$& may any day want to call for, i.e., the capitalists of the world.

A native girl, living in the Darb el Gamamiz, Cairo, has succumbed to a scorpion-bite.

The Bulgarian Government has issaed an order forbidding all Armenians quitting Egypt to enter Bulgarian territory.
Business Announcement.
Messrs. 8alinas Brothers and Co., of Alex­andria, have authorised Mr. Walter Salinas to sign for them per procuration.
Petroleum Explosion.
Advioes from Assouan report that the fire- brigade engineer and two of his subordinates have been killed by an explosion of petroleum. San 8tefano Casino.
Abounds of the Casino are informed that on Sunday next entrance to the Casino will only be free up to noon, owing to the Russian charity fete being held in the afternoon. Legislative Council.
The Legislative Counoil met yesterday to disouss a draft law regarding the judicial police, but not being in quorum, adjourned the matter to another meeting.
Rodah Island.

By arrangement with the Government, M. Z^rvudachi has been authorised to procure from Old Cairo all the earth he may require for elevating the level of the land he owns on Rodah Island, for two years and a half.
San Stefano Theatre.

The new ballet,"TheGeisha," met with great success last night, and in response to a general desire it will be given again to-morrow evening, when there will be some new debuts of artistes, inoloding Mile Marie Fleury.
Murderer 8entenoed.

The Attarin Native Court yesterday senten­ced Sayed Nasr Mastapha,a cigarette merchant at RxselTin, to 15 years' imprisonment with bard labour for the marder of Ibrahim Msha­med El Ghabashi, of Alexandria,ou the 3rd alt. Khedivial Mail Line.

Captain Fawoett, of the Khedivial Mail Line, left for England to-day via Marseilles in charge of 60 men who are to form the crew of the company's new steamer, the Osmanieh. The vessel is due to leave Southampton on the 22nd or 23rd inland Captain Fawcett expects to reach A'exandria at the end of the month, doing the voyage in a little over seven days,—reoord breaking time.
New Employment Registry.

The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by member^ requiring clerical or other assistance. Ap­plications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt. Address, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. [Advt.]

div.head: MR. COPE WHITEHOUSE'S FEARS.
div.p: TURKISH COMMISSIONERS' OBSTINATE ATTITUDE.
ALEXANDRIA DOCTOR SHOT
SQUADRON DEMANDED.

Oyetar Bay, Naw York, July 7.—Mr. Fred­erick Cope Whitehouse, of Newport, Rhode Island, came to Oyster Bay yesterday to advise President Roosevelt that the United States should rush a squadron to the Egyptian coast to protect Ameiican interests against the threatened holy war there. Secretary Loeb told Mr. Whitehouse that he did not believe the President was at this time giving bis attention to the Egyptian trouble.

Mr. Whitehouse, it will be remembered, has a claim against the Egyptian Government of many j ears' standing. He insists that bis plans for making several million acres of the Egyptian desert fertile in the Wady Rayan, was discriminated against by the English en­gineers on the Nile, and $40,000,000 is said to be the amount of reparation he has vainly sought to gain through action by the State Department.

div.head: PRECAUTIONARY MEASURES.
div.p: It has been decided, in principle, says "Al Mokattam," to inoresse the number of English officials in Egypt and to extend their powers for the purpose of maintainirg public se­curity.

div.head: ENGLISH OFFICIAL ATTACKED.
div.p: Another attaok on an Euglifh official is reported from the provinces. Mr. Marshall Arthur, of the Irrigation Department, was on a bicycle with his secretary in the neighbourhood of Kafr Beidah, in the Mit Ghamr district, whep he noticed a fellah, despite the prohibition, working bis sakieh. After a discussion he took the man to bring him before the emdeh to draw up a proeds verbal. When near the village the sons of the fellah attacked the Englishman. One of them u^set the cycle and tried to strike him when he was on the ground, hut Mr. Arthur de­fended himself successfully. The omdeh and ghaffirs came to the rescue and the assailants have been sent to the Mit Ghamr markaz, where an erqniry has been opened.

div.head: A DANGEROUS YEAR.
div.p: A Cairo correspondent writes to a London newspaper : —

1 met a man yesterday who had come from the West Coast of Africa about a month ago. He told me that the natives have been restless there for a long time past. Accord­ing to what he learnt from some men in the kuow, the year 1906 had long been fixed upon as the epoch when the "white man" would be driven out of Africa. One can credit this statement with a certain amount of truth, in the light of the wave of unrest which started in German West Afrios, and has spread to the north and the south. In some parts the motive is said to be a religious one, hut at the bottom of it all is undoubtedly race hatred.

The Mixed Commission which is engaged in the delimitation of the Turco Egyptian fron­tier is 8till encamped at Rafah. The Ottoman delegates are ignoring the acceptance by the Porte last May as the basis of a settlement of the frontier dispute, of the line from El Akaba to Rafah, and persistently oppose the inclusion within Egyptian territory of El Anjab, the site of an anoient city in ruins 35 miles south-east of Rafah. They seem disinclined to accept anything but the traditional frontier line, based on the testimony of the Bedouins inha­biting Turkish territory, a line which may be more in aooord with the natural configuration cf the country.

div.head: BRITISH BEER BREWERY (EGYPT) LIMITED.
div.p: This company has just gone to allotment, its entire working oanital having been privately subscribed. Offices have been secured in Mai- son Spiro, Chareh Kasr-el-Nil, Cairo, and Mr. A. P. Phillips has been appointed secretary. Mr. G. D. Girdwood, one of the directors, is at present in England purchasing the necessary plant, and in the meantime a suitable site has been secured near Cairo and the erection of the brewery will shortly be commenced.

The company hope to place their products, ranging from double stout to lager beers and Barton ales, upon the n&arket before the end of the year. These beers will differ from any at present on the market owing to their ex­ceptional parity, being brewed from al) malt and hops under a new English system, and Icing guaranteed free from any chemical pre servative whatever.

It is interesting to note that the importance of pore beer has recently attracted the notice of the German Reichstag, which, whilst placing no restriction upon the ingredients of beers brewed for export purposes, insists upon beer for home consumption being brewed from
barley malt" and hops only.

A terrible muider of a local medical man was perpetrated at Alexandria late last night. A young Italian gunsmith, living in the Mohar- rem Bey qoarter, went to the house in Attarin- street of a Greek doctor, by name Ver- veropoulos, in order to beg him to oome at once to attend to his mother, who was seized with a dangerous illness. The doctor refused to oome anless he receive! his fee in advance. The Italian replied that he had no money with him at the moment for he had rushed out to the doctor in a hurry, but that if the dootor would oome at once he would he paid as soon as he entered the bouse.

The dootor went with him as far as the boase but refused to enter before receiving his fee, which was £1. At this the Italian became infuriated. Drawing a revolver from his pocket he emptied two of the cham­bers into the doctor's body. He then left the house and gave himself up to the first police­man he chanoed to meet.
i* The doctor, who was aged about 35, died this morning from his wounds.

div.head: TERRIBLE TRAIN FATALITY.
div.p: Late last night we received the following telegram from our correspondent at Sohag Inspector Ortod, of the Sleeping Gar Company, was sitting npon the roof of the sleeping oar while the train was passing under Sohag bridge, when he came in contact with the bridge and his head was ont off. His body was afterwards conveyed to hospital here for an autopsy.

div.head: MUSTAPHA PASHA KAMEL'S VISIT TO ENGLAND.
div.p: THE PAN-ISLAMIC SOCIETY.
(From our Correspondent.)
London, July 27.

There was a large assembly at the reception of the Pan-Islamic Society at the Criterion Restaurant on Tuesday evening to meet Mnstapha Pasha Kamel. The company includ­ed Mr. Byles, M.P., Dr. Karl Blind, Sir Man- cherjee Bhownaggree, Mr. Swinney (president of the Positivist Society), Hamid Bey, Mme Hamid Bey, Mahomed Kahn (military attach^ to the Persian Legation), Dr. John Pollen, and many others, obiefiy representatives ot Moslems from various parts of the world. Mr. A. Sahrawardy, the energetic secretary of the society, welcomed the Pasha in an Arabic speech, and brief addresses were also delivered by Dr. Pollen, Pandit Krishnavarma (president of the Indian Home Rale Sooiety), Major Syed Hasan, late of the Icdian Medical Service, and Mr. Tarropawala, a young Parsi gentleman. The Pasha replied in Arabic, and I am able to give you a full outline translation both of his speech and of that of Mr. Sahra­wardy. Mr. Sahrawardy said :

I believe I voio9 the sentiment of every Moslem present here when J. say that the gathering of this evening is the source of greatest p'easure and pride to the Pan Islamic Sooiety. For we have assembled here to-night for the purpose of welcoming H.E. Mastapha Pasha Kamel, the well known Egyptian patriot, who has devoted himself heart and soul to the realisation of the ideal which is also the dream

div.head: EGYPTIAN DELTA LAND AND INVESTMENT CO., LTD.
div.p: LORD CROMER AS A VOLUNTEER.

Lord Cromer made a very interesting confes­sion at the Volnnteer field operations at New­lands Corner, when the Secretary for War was present, the "Daily New/' says. Lord Cromer said it was not the first time he had attended similar gatherings at Newlands Corner. In fact, at one of the meetings he very nearly carried off the prize. Few people were aware that the "Reformer of Egypt" had been a member of our citizen army.
Modai ha Pasha Kamel replied in Arabic as follows :—

Ladies and Gentlemen,—I thank you from the bottom of my heart for yoar kind words of welcome, and I can hardly find words to express in an adequate manner my feeling of gratitude. No one deserves any praise for performing his duty and I have not yet per­formed mine—so 1 hard y merit the praise which your kindness has bestowed on me. Perhaps you desire in my person to fionddr and enooarage every Egyptian devoted to Ms country and the cause of freedom. Taking & that light your words of sympathy, I request yon, on behalf of the Egyptian people, to accept their expression of most heartfelt' thanks and gratitude to you. Specially I thank Mr. Suhrawardy, whose z'alt /or the cause of truth has filled me with f)y—afop which has renewed and strengthened my hopes and aspirations. I cannot too adequately thank him for his kindness, and perhaps the first expression of thanks is the acknowledg­ment of one's abilityto do so. When I arrived in London I hardly dreamed of h wing the pleasure of assisting at such a distinguished and repiesentative gathering—an assembly con­sisting of so many Easterns and Westerns, of Hindoos, Parsees, Baddhists, Jews, Christians, and Moslems. That is why I regard this even­ing as on:qae and unparalleled in my life, an evening whose sweet and inspiring reminiscence will never fade from my memory. I am spe­cially glad to notice this sentiment of sym­pathy and goodwill towards Islam which is dawning upon the thoughtfal followers of other creeds. They are wise in encouraging this feeling of friendship. For the Renaissance of Islam mean8 the Renaissance of humanity. I therefore deem myself specially fortunate in having to-night an opportunity of addn humanity in the person of its most eulighh children. Heroes of the Empire of Inti he ye conquerors. div.head: AN EGYPTIAN BIZERTA.
div.p: Under the interrogative heading "A New B;zerta?", the "Pyramides" announces that the Government has granted a concession to an English company to cat a canal between the ancient Lake Sirbonis, west of El Aiiffi, and the Mediterranean. A spit of land, only a kilo metre w'de, separates them, and the lake has depth and accommodation sufficient for several squadrons The strategic importance of this possible naval station, says the "Pyramides," is nil, owing to the lack of elevated ground for fort?fications, and this defect would expose the quadrons inside the lake to risk of being shut in. Moreover, there is neither sweat water nor pasturage, and the stbkhas round the lake are impracticable during the rainy season. Commercially, too, the place is ot no value, for the caravan route passes it 15 miles south­ward.

div.head: CASINO FOR ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The committee appointed by the Alex andria Municipal Delegation have agreed to lend their support to Mr. George Ralli's propo­sal for a concession for a Casino on the new quay, provided that the following conditions be fulfilled

Payment of an annual rent equivalent to six per cent, on the valae of the land occupied by the Casino, the valuation to be that originally made by the Municipality in laying down the upset price of the land if sold.
The bailding is to become the property of the city of Alexandria at the expiration of fifty years dating from thi grant of the concession.
A deposit, equivalent to the annual rent of the Casino for the first five years, ia to be paid over to the Municipality.
The taxes are to bo paid by the concession naires.
The Municipality is to be entirely tree from financial responsibility of any sort or kind in regard to the Casino.

These stipulations have been accepted by the con cessionnaires with the exception that they propose that the caution money, which 'he Municipality demand should be sent as deposit equivalent to five years' rent,should he reduced to a sum equivalent to three years'rent.
We understand that M. Ponoet, the con­cession naire of the Khedivial Opera House,
Cairo, has formed an excellent opera company which is likely to give general satisfaction. The engagements so far concluded are as follows:—

div.head: NERONE.
div.p: In attempting to support the varied character of Nero, the most accomplished actor has indeed a diffionlt task,and Sig.Oiovanni Novelli; 'bdd_ Mrs peilegro' Kankam and family, Mrs. is therefore to be congratulated on having and Misg Kroiter, Mr. Moarvin Eff. Bcz'm, given last evening a very convincing repre- Mr Iraida Qiavanni, Mr. Diaoomapoalo, Mr. sentation of that vioions and depraved person- J DeigOnne> Mrs. Ephrosine Voria, Miss Sophie ality. Possessed of a fine presenoe and an p0in8njei Mr. Jacques Mallak, Mr. Vinoent excellent delivery, Sig. Novelli made the most Qij|( Monstapha Eff Fahmy. of the many opportunities with which the play J ■ abounds, and whether in the passages of love
or fury, the drunken brawl, or the oowardly I 1 suicide with which the play ends, the artiste !
was ever in evidence, and no point was missed. J Half wiy stefKno.
Sig. Novelli was ably supported by Signa who madethe most of the parts allotted to them. The
play was exceedingly well staged. It is to behoped that Nerone will be repeated.

patriotism, a lion of the forest of freedom, and a champion of the rights of humanity. Your Excellency has done well to oome here with the object of acquainting the English people with the true state of affairs in Egypt and with the aims and aspirations of the Mussulman people, and I hope and trust that they will not turn a deaf ear to the cry of the Moslem and allow religious bigotry and prejadioe to overcome their sense of justice and fairness. Even if the special object of your visit he not attained, do not be disooaraged. Your visit to Eugland is not altogether in vain. From the capital of this great empire yonr cry will reach not only your brethren in faith in the farthest corner of the globe but will also find an echo in the hearts of patriots of other countries, your partners in sofferiog. And the domain of patriotism is wider than that of Islam. A'ready I find, in the prssence, here to-Dight, of such persons as the veteran Dr. Karl Blind, the President of the Indian Home Rale Society, the President of the Positivist Sooiety, and the distinguished representative of the Par8ee community, Sir H. H. Bhownag­gree, ample proof of sympathy with your cause from people who do not belong to our faith but are oitizensof the Republic of Jastice and Humanity. Return to your beloved country and continue your struggle for freedom, and in moments of dejeotion and despair, remem­ber that you are not quite alone, that hence­forth the best wishes of the dwellers on the banks of the Rhine and the Danube, the Bosphorus and the Golden Horn, the Ganges and the Euphrates accompany the efforts of a son of the valley of the Nile, and that their eyes are directed in expectation towards the Egyptian horizon to see the break of the dawn of liberty, and the signal for the deliverance of the Children of Lhmael from the dominion of the Pharoahs aud their happy entry into the promised land of freedom. My zial over­came my discretion. Hence 1 ventured to address you in Arabic, otherwise, in the pre­sence of the Demosthenes of Egypt, reticence is the best speech and silence the best ex- pres8idn'df eloquence.

delay spells death. The malady of the Moslem nations is twofold. One I have already alluded to, the other is the absurd belief of millions of people that devotion to Islam is incompatible with progress and enlightenment. They say that our death is more profitable to mankind than our life. The contemplation of this fills the heart of every educated Moslqp and every oultured Oriental with sorrow. It is no u« referring them to the glorious pages of oui past history. It is no use pointing out to then that we owe allegiance to a liberal faith which enjoins upon us the search of knowledge fron the cradle to the grave. Our decline and fall and present degradation is living proof oontra dieting yoar assertion. You must prove it bj deeds and not by mere words. The march o events and vioissitadas in the world has proved that the strong current of science and know ledge alone can give as life aud sovereigi power. Those who march with the ourren* arrive at ths harbour of salvation. Those wh< go against it, are doomed. See how the Japan ew people, by a supreme manifestation o self-abnegation and devotion to their beloved country, have at one stroke completely refutw the allegations of the prejudiced European that the Easterns are incapable of assimilating modern progressive ideas. And, lo and behold, even England, disdaining alliance with Buro pean powers, stretches forth the hand ol friendship to Oriental Japan. One word, befor< I resume my seat, as to the charge o Mussulman fanaticism which, in season &n< out of season, issues from the wil lerness o the West. I deny this false and baseless ohargi most emphatically and categorically ; and' appeal to yoa, gentlemen, to help me ii removing the ignorance and prejudice agains Islam prevalent in the West. Gentlemen, thank yon once more for yoar kind words < weloome and expression of sympathy.

div.head: COMMISSION MUNICIPALE {Communication Officielle)
div.p: ( Suite et Fin )

Communication est ensuite donnée d'une lettre du 20 juin de la Société des tramways acceptant le renouvellement pour une année de l'entente relative à l'entietien des rues tra versées par ses lignes aux conditions fixées par la Commission dans une de ses dernières sé anoes.
Sur la demande de la Délégation, la Corn mission décide l'ouverture des crédits suivants :

i° L.B. 324, à prélever sur la réserve du budget ordinaire pour l'installation de grilles en fer aoépur des nouveaux tquares, à installer à la halte'Z'zinia et aux rues Sidi-el-Haggari et Zawiet el-Badan.
2* * LE. 100, à titre supplémentaire, à pré­lever sur la réserve du budget ordinaire, pour frais de courses du service des recettes.
3° LE. 1,600, à titre supplémentaire, pour fourniture de fourrages, dépense à régulariser ultérieurement.
4° LE. 100, à titre supplémentaire, à pré­lever sur la réserve du budget ordinaire pour frais d'éclairage du palais municipal.

Sur la proposition de la Délégation, elle au­torise la mise en adjudication de la fourniture d'un nouveau rouleau compresseur, sauf à en faire régulariser ultérieurement la dépense par la Commission, laquelle De pourra être déter­minée qu'à la suite de l'adjudication.
Elle approuve la nomination d'un ohauffeur pour la pompe automobile et charge la Déléga­tion de régler les détails de cette nomination.
La proposition tendant à la nomination d'un ingénieur mécanicien est ajournée jusqu'après la désignation de l'Ingénieur en Chef

Mention est faite de l'envoi aux membres du rapport de M. Rothacker relatif à la situation de la Municipalité vis-à-vis de certaines Sooiétés de services publics, c.a.d. les eaux, le gaz et Jeà tramways de la ville et de Ramleh.
k «r expose le but de sa proposition,

qui est trentrer en pourparlers avec les représen­tants des aites Sociétés à l'effet d'obtenir le retour à la ville après un certain temps de ces différentes entreprises qui doivent appartenir à la oolleotivité, de telle sorte que loin de consti­tuer une obarge éternelle pour la Municipalité, œlle*ci paisse à un moment donné, à l'instar des autres villes, profiter des ressources que lui oréeront ces exploitations.

La Commission, considérant l'importance de la question, ajourne à la rentrée la discussion de la proposition, mais elle prie M. Rothacker de poursaivre son étade sur certains points qu'il a déclaré ne pas avoir eu le temps d'ap profondir suffisamment, et lui adjoint M. Zer- vudaohi, en vue de la préparation des données complètes sur lesquelles doit porter l'étude de la Commission.
Communication est donnée du rapport de M. Dietrich Bey émettant l'avis qu'une largeur de 15 mètres serait suffisante pour la corniche et présenterait le moins de difficultés dans ^exécution.

1 Après une échange d'idées, la Commission <en tient à la première délibération prise par elle tendant au maintien de la largeur de 25 tnètres, dans la partie da parcours de la route qui se trouve sur les terrains de la Municipa­lité ou du Gouvernement et dans l'adoption pour la partie bordant les propriétés privées de la largeur la plus grande possible, en tenant compte de la configuration du rivage et des possibilités d'exécution, sans que toutefois la largeur dans ces parties soit inférieure à 15 mètres.

Le Président fait part de l'invitation adressée à la Municipalité d'Alexandrie par le 2me Congrès international d'assainissement et de salubrité de l'habitation et dit que la Déléga­tion a été unanime pour proposer à la Commis­sion de se faire représenter à oe Congrès par M. le Professeur Gottsohlich, en ce moment en Suisse, lequel ne manquera pas de faire profiter la ville des enseignements qui se dégageront des discussions auxquelles prendront partlessa- vants les plus autorisés, dans une matière qui intéreise aussi hautement une Municipalité souoieuse de l'hygiène et du bien-être des habi­tants.

M. le Dr. Sohiess pacha ajoute que le< préoccupations de la Municipalité étant pré­sentement dirigées vers les questions relatives aux maisons à bon marché et aux cités ouvriè­res, il y ar. .ait lieu tout en chargeant le pro- ie«seor Gots 'hlioh, de porter son attention d'une façon spéciale sur les études du Congrès car o> < questions, de l'inviter également à vhi- ter ... ouvrières les plus réputées soit en Suisse soit dans le voisinage, et de présenter un rapport sur l'ensemble de la question et sor les résultats obtenus.
La Commission approuve la proposition de la Délégation telle qu'elle est exposée par le Président.

La Commission, à l'occasion de l'examen des divers excédents et emprises soumis à son approbation, déoidr, sur ure proposition do la Délégation, et vu la note du service de la comptabilité générale, de prélever, sur le bud­get extraordinaire, une somme de L E. 8,000 pour le règlement des expropriations en cours, le orédit y relatif étant presque totalement épuisé.
Elle règle par suite divers excédents et em­prises sur états communiqués.
La Commission approuve deux arrangements proposés par le Comité du Contentieux, dans des affaires Caprara et Compagnie des E *ux et autorise l'Administration à ester en justice dans divers procès.

Sar la demande de la Délégation, elle inscrit d'urgence àl'ordreda j jurdelapré-ente séance, après en avoirinformé par dépêche le Ministère de l'Intérieur, un projet d'entente à intervenir avec le patriarcat grec pour la ceesion de tro's rues destinées à relier par les terrains du P&tri arcat et du Comte de Zogheb, la rue de Risette aux rues César et Missala.mr yennant paiement au Patriarcat d'une somme de L.E. 3 OCO.
La Commission adoptant à ce sujet la pro­
position de la Délégation, accepte la dite ces­sion au prix sas-ind qné et dans les conditions fixées par le prrjet de lettre à adresser au Patriarcat et dont l'Assemblée adopte les termes.
Etant donné que la Commission est liée par un délai d'option, la partie du procè3-verbal relative à cette question est adoptée séance tenante, aux fias de sanction d'argeDce par
S.E. le Ministre de l'Intérieur.

M. Zervudachi dit que sa proposition rela­tive à la vente des terrains en été, n'ayant pu être portée avant la séance de ce jonr, et que deux mois seulement nous séparent de l'époque où le3 ventes pourront être reprises ; que d'autre part les formalités d'approbation et de publication exigeront un délai assez long, il se réserve de la développer en temps utile pour une autre saison estivale.
La séance est levée à 7 h. p.m.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie.)
Comme hier, les affaires se sont limitées aux Delta Land, Comptoir et Agricole.
En Delta Land, l'opinion générale étant de plus en plus pessimiste, le cours tombe à 3 1/8 vendeurs.
Par contre, le Comptoir rentre en vogue et atteint 6 15/32 l'ancienne et 6 9/32 la nouvelle. Lipart de fondateur réaotionne de 43 à 42 1/2.
Quelques échanges ont eu lieu également en Delta Light, Crédit F moier Egyptien, Land Bank, Trust, Estâtes et Banque d'Orient.
Ces deux dernières valeurs reoulent la pre- mière à 1 25/32 et la seconde à 132 3/4.
Toujours plus délaissée, la Land Allotment s'inscrit à 3 5/16 l'action et 115 la part de fondateur.
L'ensemble delà cote indique une baisse peu sensible.

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny NOTES ET CRITIQUES.
div.p: Le Caire, 2 Août 1906.

A Lun ires, le tanx de l'escompte libre se maintient à 3 1/8 ponr cent. Hier, an Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a clôturé in­varié à 87 3/4, de même que l'Unifiée à 104 1/2. La National Bank a baissé d'un 1/3 à 25 1/4, tandis qae la Daïra a gagné 1/8 à 16 7/8 L'Aîrioole est demeurée inchangée à 9 5/8 et la Delta Light à 11 1/2.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien est reitée immobile à 760, ainsi que la Banque d'Athènes à 149.

Ce matin, notre marché des valeurs a été, en général, calme et inactif, avec tendance à la faiblesse. Il y a en, toutefois, un certain mouvement sor le Comptoir Financier, sur les aotious Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux, et beaucoup d'animation sur la Delta Land. Ce dernier titre a même ea les honneurs de la téanee, en oe sens du moins qu'on l'a fait redescendre, à un moment donné, jasqa'aux abords de 3 1,8.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National a perdu 3/32 à 25 7/16. L'Agricole s'est maintenue à 9 5/8-11/16. Le Comptoir Financier a été poussé jusqu'à 6 1/2 pour olôturerà 6 7/16 ; l'action nouvelle a été cotée 6 1/4. La Banque d'Abyssinie e*t remontée à

L'action Ente prise and Development est revenue à 12 et la part de fondateur à 18-18 1,2. L'action Agricole du Nil s'est inscrite à 275 ; la part de fondateur a été plus faible à 7. La Nile Land a été négociée à 13 1/16. Lei Improvements Corporation ont faibli à 4 5/8 11/16.
L'action Entreprises Immobilières et Tra­vaux a atteint 4 1/8 pour olôlurer à 4 3/32, acheteurs.

NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that the IN ANNUAL ORDINARY GENERAL MEETING of the Company will be held in Hall No. 43, Winchester House, Old Broad Street, in the City of London, on Thursday, 15th Angnst, 1906, at 1.30 o'clook p.m. pre cisely, for the purpose of receiving the Di­rectors' Report atd Balance Sheet for the half-year e ided 31,t March, 1906, electing Directors in the place of those retiring by rotation, appointing Auditors for the ensuing year and fixing their remuneration, and trans­acting the Ordinary General Bnsiness of the Company, and also for the purpose of con­sidering and, if thought fit, confirming Reso­lutions set out opposite, which were passed at an Extraordinary General Meeting held on the 19th Jnly, 1906, so to as make the same Resolutions.
Dated this 27th day of July, 1906.
By order of the Board,
F. J. HORNE, Secretary.
214, Gresham House,
Old Broad Street, London, E.C.

N.B.—Shareholders who hold Share Warrants to Bearer, and whose names are not on the Share Registers of the Company, are remind el that if they wish to attend this General Meeting of the Company, they must first deposit their Bearer Warrant?, together with a statement in writing of their names and addresses, at the Registered Offices of the Company in London two clear days before the date of the General Meeting, viz :—not later than the 13th August, 1936, or with the National Bank of E'ypt, Cairo or Alex­andria, ten clear days before the date of the General Meeting, viz not later than the 4th August, 1906. The Share Warrants re­maining so deposited until after the General Meeting shall have been held. div.head:
RUSSIAN CRISIS
THE SVEABORG MUTINY.
, FORTS SILENCED.
MUTINEERS SURRENDER.

div.p: The cannonading at Sveaborg continued throughout yesterday evening. Warships are bombarding the mutineers. A powder magazine exploded. The white Hag was hoisted late in the evening and it is rumoured that the ma- {peers have surrendered.

A wealthy Jewish member of the Duma named Herzmstein was shot dead while walk­ing with his family on the sea shore in Fin­land. The assassin eeoapei. A gendarme has been arrested who is suspected of complicity. It is believed that the crime was committed behalf of the police as a reprisal for the murders of their officials. (Reuter.)

The Sveaborg mutiny has been finally crush­ed. The battleships Tsarevitch and Slava poured in a terrific fire on the forts at short range. The mutineers replied vigorously for a time, but the battleships eventually succeed­ed in silencing the forts.

It is reported that the garrison of Fort Constantine at Kronstadt has mutinied. The other forts bombarded and eventually suc­ceeded iu silencing it Passengers arriving from Kronstadt state the soldiers have killed several officers.
(Later). It is officially stated from Krons­tadt that the mutineers have surrendered. Four c fibers have been killed and three woanded in the fighting.(Reuter.)
(Official), The Sveaborg mutineers have surrendered. Th°y will be oourt-martialled.
(Hanas)
The new Persian Grand-Vizier contemplates making political and financial reforms. (R.)

div.head:
AUSTRIA AND SERVIA.
NEW COMMERCIAL ARRANGEMENT.

div.p: The Servian Parliament has agreed to a new temporary commercial arrangement with Austria. It is hoped that a treaty will soon be concluded. (Reuter.)
M. Thomson and M. Etienne have held a
magnificent review of the rquadrons.
In a speech Admiral Fournier stated that
the manoeuvres proved that France could repel any maritime aggression, however redoubtable it might be.(Havas)
The opinion of all sections of the population here and in Johannesburg and Bloemfontein is generally favourable to the Transvaal Consti­tution. (Reuter.)
The Duchess Victoria Adelaide of Saxe- Coburg-Gotha has been safely delivered of a son. {Veuter)
General Brugkre has been operated upon for appendicitis. (Wavai)
Goodwood Cup. — Llangibby has been soratched. (Reuter)
Goodwood Cup.— 1. Plum Tree; 2. Plum Centre; 3. Gorgos. {Reuter"

House of Commons—Sir E. Grey stated that the Government has urged Persia to take immediate measures to end the present situation by satisfying the reasonable demands of the refugees.

He further stated that the Government understands that there are no longer restric­tions to the movements of foreign traders in Manchuria. A Consul General is to be appoint­ed at Mukden who, with a Consul at Newohwang, will see that British traders receive equal treatment with those of other nations. (R).

House of Lords.—The debate on the se­cond reading of the Education Bill has been opened. The speeches showed it was not in­tended to reject the measure, but the Arch­bishop of Canterbury foreshadowed important amendments with the object of seouring oom- pnlsory daily religious instruction and of testing the fitness of teachers for giving such instruction. (Rente-)
House of Commons.—Sir E. Grey empha­sized the necessity of ma:ntaining the concert of the Powers in Macedonia. He denied that no progress had been made there. (Reuter.)

div.head:
NEW COMPANIES.
MORE IN 1905 THAN IN ANY YEAR SINCE THE WAR.
div.p: The report of the Board of Trade under Seotion 29 of the Companies (Winding up) Aot, issued last week, contains some interesting reading.
During last year 1693 companies were wound op and 3967 new companies were added to the register, the net increase of companies during the year being 1162.

The deorease in the amount of nominal capital registered, which was continuous from the year 1896 to the year 1904, has, it is pointed ont, taken an upward turn, the total, £108,65^,043, oomparing with £83,914,688 in 1904. The gain is, however, very small as oon/pared with the great losses shown in the earlier years of the decade. The number of companies registered during the year 1905 also shows an increase, the total being the largest number registered in any year since the outbreak of the South African War. r

A great change has taken place during the past ten years in the character of the com­panies, and the growth in number of these with the smallest capital has been most marked. For instance, companies with a capital of between £1000 and £500 have increased very much, the respective numbers being 782 for the year 1896 and 1260 for the year 1905.
The report calls attention to a revival in the use of the prospeotas, which diminished since 1902.

div.head: MAJOR POWELL-COTTON'S EXPEDITION.
div.p: Renter's Agency has received news of Major Powell-Cotton's expedition, which left England over eighteen months ago on a jour­ney from the Nile to the Zambesi. The latest intelligence to hand by this mail is dated from Nakala, on the Upper Itnri, on May 12. This place, which is situated in the heart of the rubber district, is one of the chief haunts of the i>kapi, and here the explorer had remained for two months for the purpose ot obtaining specimens of the animal. In. this he has been successful, having preserved the complete skin and skeleton of an adult bull okapi. Major Powell Cotton hopes to secure its jartner before leaving the forest.

div.head: AN OFFICER'S MISTAKE.
div.p: A remarkable Indian snake story is tcld by General Sir Thomas Edward Gordon, K.C.B.

When asleep at night aD cfficer happened to cast his arm over the s;de of the bed, and was violently awakened by a sharp bite on one of his fiogers. Calling for a light, he and the servant who brought it on hasty exa mination decided that the punctured marks were those of snake bite, and, after tightly binding his arm in two places to stop circu­lation he proceeded with the servant's assis­tance to cut cfF the bitten finger. In the meanwhile his dogcart was made ready, and he was taken quickly to the regimental hospi­tal, where medical treatment was promptly applied. On the surgeon afterwards examining the severed portion of the finger he pronounc­ed the bite to be that of a rat !

div.head: A STRANGE PHENOMENON.
div.p: A most strange phenomenon has come to light on an island eff the Breton coast.

In the left eye of the little daughter of a fisherman, just helcw the pupil, can be seen the number 22,4. The figures are beautifully formed, and are plainly visible, even down to the comma separating the second 2 and the 4.
The local doctor can only account for it by saying that the girl's parents may have sufferei from some nervous or hysterical disorders which resulted in this number ap- v earina un the child's eve.

div.head:
TALKS WITH THE KAISER.
THE ETIQUETTE THAT IS ONLY TRANSGRESSED AT SEA.
div.p: Some interesting facts concerning the rigorous Court etiquette which the Kaiser requires from those of his snljects who come into personal contact with him are given in the rooial column of a leading Berlin journal.

Although the Kaiser is thoroughly demo­cratic in his ohoioe of acquaintances, anything approaching familiarity of conversation is ont of the question. He invites men of miscel­laneous professions and standing to bis table : a savant to-day, to-morrow a leading merchant, and the next day a sculptor. But throughout these tSte-k-tfites the guest is compelled to leave all ohoioe of subject for disoussion to the Kaiser.

Courtiers who are practised iu the art are sometimes successful in gradually leading up to the matter upon which they wish the talk to tarn, so that the Emperor himself finally introduces the subject, but the Kaiser is said to be quick to detect and frustrate any man­oeuvres of this sort.

Daring his annual Northern cruise, the Kaiser's attitude relaxes to that of comrade among comrades. He is accustomed to refer to this sea-trip as his "vacation," and is willing that the holiday atmosphere should modify the customary ceremony of his inter­course with his snbjeots. No current political topios are touched upon, except, as at Coart, when the Emperor himself broaches the sub­ject. But political matters are the only for bidden ground.

div.head:
A SYRIAN LEPER
UNCOMFORTABLE EXPERIENCES.
div.p: After experiencing what the newspapers de­scribed as scandalous and inhuman treatment, George Rossett, a Syrian leper, reaohed a retreat near New York yesterday week. Driven from his temporary home in West Virginia, he was corralled and guarded by the police and finally hoisted into a box van on the railway. Then Rosett's real troubles began. Exaggerated fears regarding contagion got abroad, and the city and State authorities gave orders and oonnter-orders with the resalt that Roaett spent seven days in the box oar like a wild beast in a cage, food and water being banded him through the bars. At last, Rossett, still entertained at the expense of the railway, was located on a siding near Baltimore, unable to move east because Philadelphia objected, or west beoauss Cumberland protested. The railway people had done their best to make the man comfortable by supplying him with pillows, food, and a bath, all free.

div.head: FRANCE AND THE PORTE.
div.p: The Constantinople oorrespoudeut of the "Temps," referring to the rumours relative to the occupation of Janet by Turkish troops in violation of the recognized rights of Franoe over that oasis, says that the French Ambas­sador has asked the Porte for explanations. The reply was that the Turkish troops had not been to Janet and had no intention of going there. This, according to the oorres pondent, oloses the inoident, whioh had its origin in the fact that in January, 1905, the Turks did oooupy the oasis and a French officer had to remove the Turkish flag which he found flying there.

div.head: SULTAN'S UNEASINESS.
div.p: Apparently, in order to prevent the corrup­tion which proceeds from evil commanioations the Turkish censorship has prohibited all reference to the Russian Dama in the local Press.

div.head: VOLCANIC DUST NUISANCE.
div.p: There is au opening for vacuum cleaners at Naples. The British Consul-General in Italy says that the reoent eruption of Vesuvius "has caused not only the houses hot even the best constructed household furniture to be filled with a penetrating powder of impal­pable fineness which olings to everything a9 it falls, and is subsequently, when quite dry, blown off by every passing draught of air. The outer walls of houses are blaok with it, and inside the carpets and curtains are in a condition which dismays oarefal househol­ders."

div.head: STROMBOLI IN ERUPTION.
div.p: The volcano of Stromboli, so well known to all travellers from Alexandria to Marseilles, after having been unquiet for some time, entered on the stage of aotive eruption last week and poured out a torrent of lava, which invaded the village of Ginestra. The inhabi­tants esoaped.

div.head: "NOTICE."
div.p: On the door of the corner house iu a street leading out of a well-known West-end rquare the following notice appears on the bra^s plate:
"This house is No. 61a, street and Dot
No. 13, square. That house is round the
corner. Do pot ring here." One oan dimly imagine (says the "Chroniole") the state of Dervons madness to which that householder was reduced before he eat down to compose snob a notice.

div.head: MURDER AND MATRIMONY.
div.p: The ohauffeur Mathieu has been sentenced to life imprisonment in the Seine Ass'ze Courts for murdering and robbing his employer, M. B^dor. Mathieu pleaded that he only meant to steal enough money to marry with, says the "Exprese," and that he had been forced to murder by M. Bddor's determined resistance. Mathieu's fiancee was in court, and went into hysterics when he was sentenced.

div.head: VACATION FOR PRINCIPLES.
div.p: A very rich and Socialistic deputy, says the "Figaro," has rented a property by the sea. He has also doted his park to pedestrians, and excluded the publio from a part of the shore, which he has reserved to himself. " What, " says one to him, "you a Socialist !" " Oh, par­don !* replies the deputy, "my oonviotions are enjoying a vacation."

div.head: BURGLAR-PROOF TOMB.
div.p: Stealing the body of a rich dead man and holding it for ransom is fairly common in America. The body of Mr. Rassell Sage has been bnried at Troy in a chilled steel case four inches thick, and weighing three tons. Electric wires are connected with this metal tomb, which will give the alarm if any attempt is made to tamper with it. The case coat over £3,000.

div.head: WOULD SAVE SUCH A LOT OF * TROUBLE.
div.p: A dear old lady, on hearing that another effort is to be made to secure the sanction of Parliament to the Channel Tunnel scheme,said she wonld be glad to see it passed, for in that event there would surely be no need for all these poor people to try to swim aoross.

div.head: UTTERLY EXHAUSTED.

Dejeoted, and Wretohedly Weak, with Unbearable Baok Paine.
Sinking; into Deepondenoy.
Dr. Williams' Pink Pills For Pale People
Drought back Health and Vigour.

"I first had a curious feeling of weariness," said Mr. Line, *'that co rest wonld dispel. Throughout the day I was worried with this strange sensation of fatigae, and no matter how heavily I slept at night I would rise the next morning just as weary and depressed. In time I became utterly exhausted, and though I oontinned to go to business I was not fit for work ; in faot, at the end of the day I felt almost dead. Sometimes I could hardly walk ; a dull irritating pain settled in the middle of my back, succeeded at times by shooting pains which became unbearably intense. A change came over my appearance ; I was pale and oareworo, and my eyes were sunken. All energy was sapped ont of my body, and though medical men and acquaintances advised various medicines nothing gave assistance.

"I had almost lost hope of recovery when I remembered having read of many cures by Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People. It was like an inspiration. I bought a box and took the pills according to directions. They seemed to ronse me from my despondent state, and with two boxes I felt that health was returning. By persevering with the pills I overcame the terrible feeling of exhaustion, and with a few boxes my care was complete. Thanks to Dr. Williams' Pink Pills I have completely regained health, strength, and spirits, and business is once more a pleasure."

div.head: Municipalité d'Alexandre.
A v 1 s
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les
travaux de terrassement de la route de 30m.
depuis la rue El Chatby jusqu'à la tranohée de
.Tbrahimieh.
Le cautionnement est fixé à L.E. 190,
Le cahier des charges est déposé au Bureau
Central Technique où il petit être oonsulté
par les intéressés tous les jours de9 h. » midi
les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adresàées sous pli
cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la
Municipalité avant le 14 Août.
Elles pourront également être déposées en
séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5 h. p m.
L'enveloppe devra en outre porter la men-
tion "Soumission pour Travaux de terrasee-
ment de la route de 30 m."
Le cautionnement on le reça d'une banque
devra être remis au Service de la Comptabilité
Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et an
plus tard le 14 Août à midi.
ToQte offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions
ci-dessus sera écartée.
Le Vioe-Président,
(Signé) Dr. Schiess.
Alexandrie, le 30 Juillet 1906. 28289-3-3
AVIS
Le mardi quatorze (14) Août proohain, la
Municipalité procédera à la vente des pierres
de taille (blocs) provenant de la démolition de
la tour dite des "Romains."
Chaque soumissionnaire devra déposer un
cautionnement de L E. 5 '.
Le prix devra être donné par mètre eabe de
pierres brutes telles qu'elles se trouvent sur le
chantier.
L'acheteur, on son dé'égué, pourra assister
au m es u rage des pierres qui sera commencé le
lendemain de la veute et devra effectuer le
paiement intégral à la Caisse Municipale un
jour après le mesnrage.
11 aura à supporter les droits de carrière an
profit de la ville et devra enlever les pierres
achetées dans un délai d'un mois sous peine
de folle enchère pour compte de l'adjudica-
taire.
Les offres devront être adressées, sous pli
caoheté, à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la
Municipalité avant le 14 Août proohain. Elles
pourront également être déposées en séance de
la Délégation le même jour à 5 h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter, en outre, la men-
tion: (Soumission pour l'aobat des pierres
provenant de la démolition de la toar des
Romains."
Le cautionnement oa le reça d'une banque
agrée par la Municipalité, devra être remis
séparément au Service de la Comptabilité
Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus
tard le 14 Août 1906 à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les oonditions
oi-dessas sera écartée.
Alexandrie, le 30 Juillet 1906.
Le Vice Président,
28297 3-3 (Sigué) : Dr. Schiess.
AVIS
La Municipalité met en adjudication la Cana-
lisation et le Macadamisage de la Rue Abou-
Nawatieh.
Le cautionnement est fixé à L.E. 100.
Le cahier des charges est dépoeé au Bureau
de la Voirie ou il peut être oonsulté par
les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi,
les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sons plis
cachetés à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la
Municipalité avant le 14 Acû". 1906. ,
Elles pourront également être déposées en !
séance de la Dé'égatiou le même j our à 5 h. p.m. 1
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la men- ,
tion : "Soumission pour la Canalisation et le
Macadamisage Rue Abon-Nawat:eb.
Le cautionnement on le reça d'une banque
d'après les conditions du cahier des charges,
devra être remis séparément au Service de la
Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouvertnre des
offres et au plus tard le 14 Août prochain à
midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions
ci-de38ns sera écartée.
(Signé) Dr. Schiess
Alexandrie, le 30 Juillet 1906.

div.head: CAISSE DE SECOURS RUSSE
div.p: FÊTE DE BIENFAISANCE-
GRANDE UOTERIE
Dimanche, 5 août, aura lieu, au Casino de
San Stefano, nue fête de bienfaisance organisée
par le Comité de la Caisse de Secours russe,
dont M. d'Abazs, conseiller à la Cour d'Appel
Mixte, a bien voulu accepter la présidence
d'honneur.
Uu des olous du programme, qae nous
publierons en détail, sera le tirage d'nne
loterie, dont voioi les lots :
1er lot: une Automobile de 5 1/2 H. P. des "Officine Turkheimer" de Milan.
2me lot : une Obligation à lot 3 % du Crédit Foncier Egyptien.
3me lot : une Obligation à lot 3 % du Crédit Foncier Egyptien.
4me lot: une Obligation à lot 3 % du Crédit Foncier Egyptien.
5me lot : un Bon à lot du Panama.
6me lot : do. do.
7melot: do. do.
L'automobile portée comme 1er lot est celle qui a gagné la course de Milan-Sau Rsmo.
Les billeta de cette loterie sont déjà en vente. Prix da billet P.T. 5.
Le comité d'organisation de la fête de bien- faisanoe est ainsi composé :

MM. Nicolas D'Abaza, Conseiller à la Coar d'Appel, Président honoraire ; A. D'Abaza, Président ; B. Campos et Emile de Menasce, trésoriers ; R. G. Canivet, secrétaire général ; MM. le miralai Hopkinson bey, de Baoh, J. Montafoff, Dr. Camerini, Claude J. R)lo, Alex­andre Tilohe, Emile Cattaui, Edmond de Me­nasce, Maurice Herzenstein, Herman Agbion,
Alohewski, A. Zamorani. membres.
Les billets de la loterie sont mis en vente au prix de P.T. 5.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
